critical_note.message: This brief MUST be reviewed by First Nations partners before any article is written. Non-Indigenous people should not write about First Nations partnerships without community guidance and approval.

why_this_story_matters: First Nations young people are 17x more likely to be in detention - this is the central injustice JusticeHub addresses
Partnership approach must be transparent and accountable
Models ethical practice for other organisations
Builds trust with First Nations communities considering partnership
purpose.who_should_write_this: Ideally co-authored with First Nations partners, or written by First Nations team members. If written by non-Indigenous staff, requires thorough community review.

content_areas: 17x overrepresentation is a result of systemic racism and colonisation
Youth justice system has historically failed First Nations young people
Many 'solutions' have been imposed without community input
ACT acknowledges its position as a non-Indigenous-led organisation
acknowledgment.tone: Honest, not performative. Name the problem clearly.

from_brand_docs.radical_humility: We don't have all the answers, but we're cultivating solutions together
from_brand_docs.decentralised_power: Communities lead; we support. Every tool has a sunset clause and 'forkable' IP
from_brand_docs.obsolescence_design: We design for our own obsolescence. 40% of profits flow to community ownership

practical_application: Community-led design: First Nations communities shape features and priorities
Data sovereignty: Indigenous data stays in Indigenous control
Forkable IP: Communities can take and adapt the technology
Sunset clauses: JusticeHub plans for community ownership, not dependency

principles: Indigenous data is collected, owned, and controlled by Indigenous peoples
Data about Indigenous peoples should benefit Indigenous peoples
Indigenous communities decide how their data is used
Cultural protocols are built into technology, not added as an afterthought
implementation_in_justicehub: Elder approval workflows for culturally sensitive content
sources_to_reference: Maiam nayri Wingara Indigenous Data Sovereignty Collective
CARE Principles for Indigenous Data Governance

cultural_safety.definition: Cultural safety goes beyond cultural awareness or sensitivity. It requires recognising and addressing power imbalances, creating environments where First Nations people feel safe to express their identity.
in_practice: Empathy Ledger integration: Stories shared on storyteller's terms
Cultural sensitivity levels for content classification

specific_partnerships.note: This section needs input from partnerships team - what can be shared publicly?
questions_for_team: Which partnerships can be named publicly?
Are there quotes or stories from partners that can be included?
What upcoming partnership work is in development?

content_areas: Acknowledging colonisation's ongoing impact on youth justice
Naming systemic racism when we see it
Platform commitment to amplifying First Nations voices

structure.approach: Traditional Owner acknowledgment specific to where JusticeHub operates. Not generic - meaningful.
Name the 17x overrepresentation and its causes clearly. Truth-telling, not euphemism.
Honest about ACT's position as non-Indigenous-led. What we're learning.
How we approach partnership - community-led, data sovereignty, obsolescence design.
Specific examples of how Indigenous data sovereignty is implemented in JusticeHub.
What cultural safety means in the platform - Empathy Ledger, consent, elder approval.
Specific partnership work (with community approval to share).
How First Nations communities and organisations can engage - on their terms.

tone_guidance.voice: Humble, honest, accountable. Not performative or self-congratulatory.
do: Name Traditional Owners specifically when possible
Reference established principles (CARE, Maiam nayri Wingara)
Be concrete about what we actually do, not just what we aspire to
avoid: Performative acknowledgments that don't lead to action
Using First Nations partnership as marketing

review_process.step_1: Share this brief with First Nations team members for initial feedback
review_process.step_2: Determine who should write/co-author the article
review_process.step_3: Gather input from current partnerships on what can be shared
review_process.step_6: Final approval from First Nations team
review_process.estimated_timeline: This should not be rushed. Allow time for proper consultation.

recommended_reading: Maiam nayri Wingara Indigenous Data Sovereignty Collective
CARE Principles for Indigenous Data Governance
external_resources.note: These resources can help inform the article but don't replace community consultation.
